questions.text:
Which of the following statements matches the diagnosis of acute respiratory distress in a child?
1) Within 7 days of known insult
2) Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or LV dysfunction
3) New Chest Infiltrates
4) PaO2/FiO2: 100-200 mm Hg
questions.solution:
The criteria listed match the definition of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), which includes:

Within 7 days of a known insult: ARDS typically develops within 7 days of the inciting event (e.g., pneumonia, trauma, aspiration).

Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or LV dysfunction: This indicates that ARDS is primarily a pulmonary issue, not due to heart failure.

New chest infiltrates: Chest X-ray or CT shows new, bilateral infiltrates indicative of ARDS.

PaO2/FiO2: 100-200 mm Hg: This range falls within the classification of moderate ARDS, based on the PaO2/FiO2 ratio.

Thus, all the given points are correct and align with the diagnostic criteria for ARDS in children.

 

Key takeaways:-Paediatric ARDS guideline

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: In the mid epigastric area

questions.text: A 4-week-old child presents to the hospital with a complaint of projectile, non-bilious vomiting associated with movable, olive-shaped abdominal mass, 2.5 cms in length is seen especially after feeding. In which of the following regions, this abdominal mass can be best palpated?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario of projectile, non-bilious vomiting and a movable, olive-shaped abdominal mass, the most probable diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS).

In CHPS, the mass is typically located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, just to the right of the midline, often below the liver margin.

Key takeaways:- CHPS

Definition: Thickening of the pyloric muscle, causing obstruction between the stomach and duodenum.

Epidemiology:

Age of presentation: 2 weeks to 3 months

More common in males than females

Clinical Presentation:

- Projectile Vomiting: Non-bilious, progressing to projectile after feeding

- Olive-Shaped Mass: Movable, often found in the right upper quadrant, below the liver margin

(hallmark feature)

- Dehydration&Weight Loss: Due to poor food retention

Diagnosis:

-Ultrasound: First-line tool, shows thickened pyloric muscle

- Blood Tests: Hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to prolonged vomiting

Treatment:

- Surgical Intervention: Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the definitive treatment

- Preoperative Stabilization: Correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 1 year old baby with diarrhea presented with restlessness, sunken eyes but was able to drink water. Skin turgor goes back in 2 sec. Best management is?
questions.solution:
In given case mental status:restlessness,sunken eyes,able to drink water suggestive of some dehydration .For some diarrhoea we will for Plan B.

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

Temper tantrums and breath-holding spells:both are classified as neurobehavioral disorders, not habit disorders.

involve some degree of the nervous system (autonomic nervous system, central nervous system)

These behaviors are involuntary and not under conscious control

Key takeaways:-

Habit disorders are repetitive, unconscious behaviors often starting in childhood

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Resuscitation of a neonate with HR < 60/min includes all of the following except?
questions.solution:
In early part of resuscitation we do perform initial steps

I)Maintain temperature/provide warmth to child

ii)Dry the child by towel

iii)Tectile stimulation

iv)Positioning of the baby

v)Clear airway

Under tectile stimulation we do rubbing the back &Trickling/Flicking the sole.

Slapping the back is wrong method because it can cause trauma to child.We actually do rubbing the back in which we give strong tactile stimulation from top to bottom or bottom to top of back.

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can result in dactylitis?
questions.solution:
Dactylitis is a common manifestation in sickle cell anemia due to vaso-occlusion in the small bones of the hands and feet, which can cause pain and swelling.

Other options:-

Hemophilia: Characterized by bleeding disorders, not dactylitis.

Von Willebrand Disease 1: A bleeding disorder that doesn't cause dactylitis.

Thalassemia: Can cause bone changes, but not typically dactylitis.

Key takeaways:-

Dactylitis, also known as"sausage digit,"refers to the painful swelling of fingers or toes, often due to inflammation.

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the CNS imaging done in a child, as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given imaging shows an empty region posteriorly, likely a cystic mass, along with hypoplasia of the posterior fossa structures. These are classic features of Dandy-Walker malformation.

Other options:-

Cerebellar Vermis Hypoplasia: Underdevelopment of the cerebellar vermis, often associated with various syndromes. The vermis appears small or absent on imaging.

Mega Cistern Magna: A benign condition with a large cisterna magna, typically asymptomatic and not associated with cerebellar changes

Key takeaways:-

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Cutis marmorata is a condition seen in neonates due to exposure to?
questions.solution:
Cutis marmorata is a condition seen in neonates due to exposure to cold temperature.

Key takeaways:-

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Raised AFP can be seen
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignancy seen

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Ataxia Telangiectasia?
questions.solution:
In Ataxia Telangiectasia, raised alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are commonly observed.

Other options:

Autosomal dominant - Ataxia Telangiectasia is actually an autosomal recessive disorder.

Telangiectasia since birth – Telangiectasias typically develop later in childhood, not from birth.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignancy seen- The most common malignancies in Ataxia Telangiectasia are lymphomas and leukemias, not squamous cell carcinoma.

Key takeaways:

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Serum levels of factor VIII are decreased

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Other options

Deficiency of Factor IX - characteristic for Hemophilia B, not for A.

Raised PT -Typically normal in Hemophilia A.

Reduced APTT and FDPs - APTT is prolonged in Hemophilia A, not reduced.

Key takeaways:

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Phenylketonuria occurs due to deficiency of?
questions.solution:
According to Nelson textbook 90-95% cases of PKU is due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine Hydoxylase & 3-5% cases are due to deficiency of cofactor of phenylalanine Hydoxylase enzyme(Tetra hydro biopterin).

Key Takeaway :-

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Which among the following is the last fontanelle to close in a child?
questions.solution:
Anterior fontanelle is last to close in child

Posterior fontanelle is first to close in child.

Key takeaways:-

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Criteria for Neurofibromatosis-1 include all except?
questions.solution:
Other options:-

Acoustic neuroma:characteristic of Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), not NF1. NF2 is more commonly associated with bilateral acoustic neuromas.

Optic nerve tumors - Commonly seen in NF1, including optic gliomas.

Pseudoarthrosis of tibia - A characteristic feature, involving the development of a false joint in the tibia.

Cafe-au-lait spots - Typically present in NF1, these are light brown spots on the skin

Key takeaways:-

NF1 (Neurofibromatosis Type 1) AD Mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17

NF2 (Neurofibromatosis Type 2) AD Mutation in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22

Diagnostic criteria of NF1

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Ideal time gap between two live vaccines, if both can't be given together, should be?
questions.solution:
If two live vaccines cannot be given together, there should be a gap of at least 1 month (or 4 weeks) to ensure that the antibodies developed from the first vaccine do not interfere with the effectiveness of the second vaccine.

Key takeaways:-

-There is no need to keep a gap of 1 month between a live vaccine and a killed (inactivated) vaccine. They can be given at the same time or at different intervals

-All live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy & immunocompromised except

During outbreaks &travel (YF,OPV,Cholera) & bite case (rabies)

-If two live vaccines are given together, they should be administered at different injection sites.

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Bernard-Soulier Syndrome occurs due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Bernard-Soulier Syndrome is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of GpIb, a receptor on platelets necessary for binding to vWF(von Willebrand factor).

Other options:

vWF – Deficiency causes von Willebrand Disease, affecting platelet adhesion.

Fibronectin - Involved in wound healing and cell adhesion; not linked to specific bleeding disorders.

GpIIb/IIIa - Abnormality causes Glanzmann Thrombasthenia, leading to defective platelet aggregation

Key takeaways:-

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Galactosemia occurs most commonly due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Most common cause of classic galactosemia is enzymes Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyltransferase deficiency , leading to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate,which causes liver damage, cataracts, and intellectual disability if untreated.

Other options:-

Epimerase –Deficiency of UDP-galactose 4’-epimerase causes a rarer form of galactosemia

Galactokinase –Deficiency of galactokinase leads to a mild form of galactosemia, often presenting with cataracts.

HGPRTase –Deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRTase) causes Lesch-Nyhan syndrome/self mutilating syndrome.

Key takeaways:-Galactosemia

-AR inheritance

- Most Common Enzyme Deficiency: Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT).

Other Enzyme Deficiencies:

Galactokinase (GALK): Causes a milder form, primarily cataracts.

UDP-Galactose 4'-Epimerase (GALE): Rare; may present with mild or severe symptoms.

-Inability to convert galactose into glucose leads to the accumulation of toxic metabolites such as

galactose-1-phosphate, galactitol, and galactonate, causing multisystem damage

-Clinical features:Symptoms appears when breast feeding is done,that’s why it is considered

contraindication for Breast Feeding.specialised formula feed needs to be given .

Hypoglycaemia,Neonatal cholestasis,sepsis(commonly by E.coli),renal

damage(Acute Tubular Necrosis),Cataract(oil drop cataract),Seizure & mental retardation

-prevention of complications:-eliminate milk from diet,go for specialised formula feed.

Oil drop cataract in galactosemia

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Which disease has not been covered routinely under Mission Indradhanush?
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush was launched in December 2014 with the objective of achieving full immunization coverage for more than 90% of infants by the year 2020. "Indradhanush" is a Hindi word for rainbow, symbolizing the seven diseases targeted in the mission.

Diseases Covered in Mission Indradhanush:

Diphtheria

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

Tetanus

Polio

Tuberculosis

Measles

Hepatitis B

Mission Indradhanush later expanded to cover Japanese Encephalitis ,HiB(Hemophilus influenzae B)and Rotavirus .

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Drug most commonly used for fetal lung maturity to prevent HMD postnatally is?
questions.solution:
Betamethasone is commonly used to promote fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of HMD(Hyaline Membrane Disease) when preterm delivery is anticipated.

Other options:-

Dexamethasone can also be used but is less commonly preferred compared to betamethasone for fetal lung maturity.

Prednisolone does not cross the placenta effectively, so it is not used for fetal lung maturity.

Folic Acid is a vitamin important for neural tube development, not for lung maturity.

Key takeaways:-HMD(Hyaline Membrane Disease)

ref :Nelson textbook of paediatric
